Creating a Learning Community for Solutions to Climate Change

Federal Award ID: NSF 0950396

Project Outcomes Report

Human-caused Climate Change is one of the most serious problems facing humanity. Burning of fossil fuels, such as gas, oil and coal, have released heat-trapping gases into the atmosphere. Atmospheric concentrations of these gases are at levels that have not been experienced in the history of life on Earth. The result is a rapidly warming planet, changes in historical patterns of rainfall and snowfall, and increased weather extremes including storms and drought, as well as dramatic changes in the chemistry of the oceans. The consequences of these developments are already affecting human health, environmental quality, agriculture, and the economy.

Solutions to runaway climate change can be found in every economic sector – including transportation, housing, agriculture and consumer behavior.

Because of the magnitude of the problem and the speed at which the climate is changing, solutions to rapid climate change involve all countries and all people.

The multi-disciplinary nature of climate change and climate solutions makes it a very difficult topic for education. Few faculty members and other educators have the depth and breadth of knowledge nor the pedagogical skills to cover the full range of causes, consequences, solutions and actions related to climate change.

Our approach to better prepare educators to teach about climate change was to create the Climate Adaptation and Mitigation e-Learning (CAMEL) web resource at www.CAMELclimatechange.org . The CAMEL site is a free, comprehensive, interdisciplinary and multi-media resource with 300 topic areas, 21 content types (such as course syllabi) and over 1,400 curricular materials for college faculty and other  educators. The topics are organized in a way that shows how the topics are related to climate change causes, consequences, solutions and actions. CAMEL’s powerful cyber platform provides topic and content type filtering to allow the user to find specific types of materials and the appropriate grade level needed. It provides multiple social media tools for networking and dissemination.

Since the site went public in December 2011, there have been over 175,000 sessions by 140,000 unique visitors to CAMEL website according to Google analytics.   We have reached users from over 150 countries and territories. The greatest users outside the US (55%) have been India, United Kingdom, Canada, Australian and the Philippines in that order. Slightly more than half of the users have been male. One third of the users (33%) were between the ages of 25-34; 27.5% were between ages 18-24,  and 15.5% and 12.5% between the ages of 35-44 and 45-64 respectively. Use continues to be strong with more than 21,000 unique visitors making nearly 27,000 visits since August 2014.

The CAMEL project team, including faculty and students from more than a dozen universities has conducted over  than 50 workshops, webinars and presentations to teach faculty members how to use the CAMEL site to find the content and tools that they need.  Team members have conducted more than 100 public talks, including at schools and churches, and have appeared on TV and radio to reach a wide-range of audiences. We have made use of social media, including Facebook and Twitter.

The CAMEL project received supplemental funds from NSF to partner with the American Indian Higher Education Consortium (AIHEC) to train Tribal College and University (TCU) faculty in the use of CAMEL resources, develop TCU faculty as part of CAMEL community, and pilot partnerships between TCU and faculty from other institutions to share teaching resources and approaches, working in cross-institutional teams ...
